video.title: Dart Programming Tutorial - Full Course
video.description:
Learn the Dart programming language in this full tutorial for beginners. Dart is a strictly typed programming language that is used in the Flutter framework to develop cross platform mobile apps.

Since Dart supports both AOT (Ahead of time) and JIT (Just In Time) compilation, it delivers extremely fast development cycles and fast execution and startup times. It is a compiled programming language and can also transpile the code into JavaScript.

💻 Course from Mahmud Ahsan. 
🔗 Mahmud's Youtube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCtHlgyUw0wLE5Ous9swfFlg
🔗 Mahmud's Github: https://github.com/mahmudahsan/
🔗 Mahmud's Blog: https://thinkdiff.net/

🔗 Dart language: https://dart.dev/
🔗 Flutter Framework: https://flutter.dev/

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:32) Setup
⌨️ (0:03:50) Fundamentals
⌨️ (0:11:04) Data Types
⌨️ (0:15:44) String, Type Conversion, Constant, null
⌨️ (0:23:50) Operators
⌨️ (0:39:13) Loop
⌨️ (0:48:03) Collections [ List, Set, Map ]
⌨️ (1:01:07) Function
⌨️ (1:13:49) Class
⌨️ (1:37:41) Exception Handling
⌨️ (1:41:26) Conclusion

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.text:
Compile time vs Runtime

Compile-time and Runtime are the two programming terms used in the software development. Compile-time is the time at which the source code is converted into an executable code while the run time is the time at which the executable code is started running.

topLevelComment.author: khalil zakaria Zemmoura
topLevelComment.text: Hi Mahmoud, thank you for this greet tutorial. I wanna just point you that even for dynamically typed languages. The type is known at compile time because Python, Ruby and JS are compiled to bytecode then the byte code is interpreted. The difference between static and dynamic is in the types of values a variable can take. In dynamic you can assign a different type to a  variable without complains from the the interpreter which is not possible in static languages. And yes compiled languages are static and what we call interpreted languages are mostly dynamic.

replies.author: Simon Chesney
replies.text:
i have this same problem too. for a quick fix, go into your file directories, and get the file location of the dart application in the dart sdk folder. that whole string of text will replace the word dart when compiling. 
for example:
C:\Users\Dell\Documents\dartsdk-windows-x64-release\dart-sdk\bin\dart 



instead of typing playground.dart afterwards, you also need to type in the file location of your playground.dart file
for example: 
C:\Users\Dell\Desktop\playground\playground.dart


alternative(but better) solution:
you can go into the settings of visual studio code and change the path for both of these things. i personally don't know how, but at least the above solution will allow you to simple compile your code in the first place

topLevelComment.author: 3d adventures
topLevelComment.text:
At 11:25, the terminology is wrong. Strongly typed languages need not have their variables known at compile time. It means that data will not be implicitly converted when performing operations between incompatible datatypes. Python is a strongly typed language, not a weakly typed language.


What you're talking about is "Static typing", which is contrasted by "Dynamic typing". "Strong typing" is contrasted by "Weak typing".

topLevelComment.text: The information seen on screen at 11:28 is false. C++ is a weak, statically typed language. Python is a strong, dynamically typed language. "Strong" and "Dynamic" are not comparable because you can be both, one, or neither at the same time.

topLevelComment.author: Matcha Lover
topLevelComment.text:
A very good video, @Mahmud Ahsan. Thank you for your hard work! However i got two suggestions. 
1. What or who is your audience? Tell it in the beginning of your videos.
2. Depending on your audience try to keep the explanations as simple and brief as possible.
I'm a prof. software engineer/architect and for me the video has far to much on the very basics of the basics.
If you are doing it for professionals then you don't have to explain how a loop or function/method/procedure works etc.
Many of us love videos because we are reading lots and lots documentations during the day and thus it is sometimes 
pretty nice to watch or listen to some sort of video. But yes in the end it all boils down to the documentation if things get serious.
Also, your english is awesome! Keep it up.
